elements.name: childNomineeFormal
elements.title: Was {childNomineeName} formally appointed to help {childName} manage their money and legal decisions?
elements.description:
These are the ways someone can be formally appointed.
  • {childName} could have signed a document that gave someone else the power of attorney using the Power of Attorney Act,
  • {childName} could have signed a document that appointed someone as a representative using the Representation Agreement Act, or
  • a person can be appointed by the Court using the Patients Property Act,
  • a person could have been appointed either the Minister of Aboriginal Affairs and Northern Development or by the Court using the Indian Act

elements.name: childNomineeFormalYesExplanation
elements.title:
The Public Guardian and Trustee (PGT) will need a copy of the legal document that proves that {childNomineeName} was formally appointed as {childName}'s nominee.

You can get a head start by asking {childNomineeName} for that document now, or, you can wait for this service to remind you in a later step.

For now, please continue answering questions about {childNomineeName}.

elements.name: childNomineeFormalNoExplanation
elements.title:
Even if {childNomineeName} was not formally appointed to help {childName}, it is still best to let both {childNomineeName} and {childName} know that you are applying for a Representation Grant.

This service will tell you how to let them know in a later step.

For now, please continue answering questions about {childNomineeName}.

elements.name: childDiedAfter
elements.title: Did {childName} die after {deceasedDateOfDeathPlus4}?

elements.name: childDiedAfterFAQ1
elements.title: Why does this date matter?
elements.body:
Under the law, in order for {childName} to qualify for {deceasedName}'s `assets`, {childName} must have lived for at least 5 days after {deceasedName} died. Once {childName} has qualified, it doesn't matter if {childName} is now dead.

The people managing {childName}'s belongings need to know that you are applying for a Representation Grant for {deceasedName}.

For more information, click here for the Five-day survival rule from the Wills, Estate and Succession Act (WESA). (This link opens in a new tab)

elements.name: childDiedAfterNoGchildExists
elements.title: Did {childName} have any children?

elements.name: childDiedAfterNoGchildExistsFAQ1
elements.title: Do I include {childName}'s legally adopted children?
elements.body:
Yes, you must include {childName}'s legally adopted children. All of {childName}'s biological and legally adopted children need to know that you are apply for a Representation Grant.

If you are not sure if a person was legally adopted by {childName} or not, it is safer for you to include this person. You want as much transparency in your application as possible in case this person was legally adopted by {childName}.

Even though you are telling this person you are applying for a Representation Grant, they don't automatically get part of {childName}'s `estate`.

elements.name: childDiedAfterNoGchildExistsFAQ2
elements.title: Do I include {childName}'s step-children?
elements.body:
No, you do not need to include {childName}'s step-children because {childName} did not legally adopt them. Only {childName}'s biological or legally adopted children need to know that you are apply for a Representation Grant.

If you are not sure if a person was legally adopted by {childName} or not, it is safer for you to include this person. You want as much transparency in your application as possible in case this personal was legally adopted by {childName}.

Even though you are telling this person you are applying for a Representation Grant, they don't automatically get part of {childName}'s `estate`.

elements.name: childDiedAfterNoGchildExistsFAQ3
elements.title: Do I include {childName}'s children (biological or legally adopted) that were legally adopted by someone else?
elements.body:
The answer depends if {childName} was alive when someone else legally adopted their children, and, if {childName} gave up their parenting rights or not.

If {childName} was alive at the time someone else legally adopted {childName}'s children, and {childName} gave up their parenting rights, {childName}'s former children DO NOT need to be included.

If {childName} had already died when {childName}'s children were legally adopted by someone else, these children DO need to be included.

If {childName} was alive when {childName}'s children were legally adopted by someone else, but {childName} did not give up their parenting rights, these children DO need to be included.

This last situation may happen if the children's other parent(s) gave up their parenting rights but {childName} still kept their parenting rights.

If you are not sure if someone who has been adopted is still considered {childName}'s child or not, it is safer for you to include this person. You want as much transparency in your application as possible in case the Court considers this person {childName}'s child.

Even though you are telling this person you are applying for a Representation Grant, if they are not {childName}'s child anymore, they don't automatically get part of {childName}'s `estate`.

For more information, click here to read about who should be included as {childName}'s children, if they were adopt, from the Adoption Act. (This link opens in a new tab)

elements.name: childDiedAfterNoGchildExistsFAQ4
elements.title: Do I need to include {childName}'s children-in-law?
elements.body: No, you do not need to include {childName}'s children-in-law (the `spouses` of {childName}'s biological or legally adopted children).

elements.name: childDiedAfterNoGchildExistsNoExplanation
elements.title: Because {childName} died before {deceasedDateOfDeathPlus4} and {childName} did not have children, the people managing {childName}'s belongings do not need to know that you are applying for a Representation Grant for {deceasedName}.

elements.name: childDiedAfterNoGchildExistsYesTempError
elements.title: For now, this service has only been developed for a limited number of situations. At this time, this service cannot help you apply for a Representation Grant.

elements.name: childDiedAfterYesExplanation
elements.title:
Because {childName} has died after {deceasedDateOfDeathPlus4}, {childName}'s `personal representative` needs to know that you are applying for a Representation Grant for {deceasedName}.

It is your responsibility to check with {childName}'s family and friends to find out who is {childName}'s personal representative.

If you find out that {childName} does not have a personal representative, this service will help you tell that to The Court.

elements.name: childHasPersonalRep
elements.title: Do you know if {childName} has a `personal representative`?
elements.description:
If {childName}'s personal representative is not alive anymore, contact that person's personal representative to find out who is now representing {childName}.

If someone is planning on becoming {childName}'s personal representative but hasn't done so yet, it is safer for you to include them as {childName}'s personal representative.

elements.name: childHasPersonalRepDKError
elements.title:
Because you are not sure if {childName} has a personal representative, you may want to check with as many of {childName}'s family and friends as you can find.

If {childName}'s family or friends do not know if {childName} has a personal representative, one option may be hiring a professional investigator to try and find out for sure.

Examples of professional investigators include private investigators, heir tracers and other similar services.

For transparency of your application, you want to show the court all efforts made to find out whether {childName} has a personal representative. The Court will ultimately decide whether sufficient effort has been made to find this information.
